H0.text: Predatorâ€‘prey is the relationship type illustrated by a tick attaching to a deer and consuming its blood, thereby harming the deer.

H1.text: Mutualism is the type of relationship in which a tick attaches to a deer, consumes its blood, and harms the deer.

H2.text: Parasite-host is the relationship type that occurs when a tick attaches to a deer, consumes its blood, and harms the deer.

H3.text: Commensalism is the type of relationship exemplified by a tick attaching to a deer and consuming blood, harming the deer.

A4.text: Parasites do not kill their hosts

A5.text: Parasitism is a kind of symbiosis, a close and persistent long-term biological interaction between a parasite and its host. Unlike saprotrophs, parasites feed on living hosts... the parasitic relationship harms the host
